Distribution class¶

It represents a probability distribution on a set of elements.

class Distribution¶

Variables

int num_el¶

The number of elements in the set. It is also equal to prob.size().

std::vector<long double> prob¶

It contains the probability of ocurrence of each element from a set.

Each value prob[i] is the probability of ocurrence of the ith element. The vector is indexed starting at position 0.

Note

The vector prob is valid when all the elements are in the interval \([0,1]\) and the sum of all numbers in the vector is 1 with margin of error (upper or lower) equals to a constant epsilon by default set as 10e-6.

Constructors

Distribution()¶

Default constructor.

Distribution(std::string file)¶

Constructor used when the probability distribution is in a file.

Parameters

file –

File name that contains a probability distribution. The file format must be the following:

n
p1
p2
...
pn

where n is the number of elements in the set and pi is the probability of the ith element ocurring.

Distribution(std::vector<long double> &prob)¶

Constructor used when there is already a probability distribution in a vector.

Parameters

prob – A vector containing a probability distribution.

Distribution(int num_el, std::string type)¶

Constructor used to generate a uniform or a random probability distribution.

Parameters

  • num_el – Number of elements in the set.

  • type – Must be "uniform" for generating a uniform distribution or "random" for a random distribution.

Public functions

std::string toString(int precision)¶

Generates a string with the probability distribution.

Parameters

precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

Returns

A string containing the probabilities. The number of digits after de decimal point for each value will depend on precision. Each two values are separated by a space.

void printToFile(std::string file, int precision)¶

Prints the probability distribution in a file.

Parameters

  • file – File name.

  • precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

The probability distribution will be printed in the following format:

n
p1
p2
...
pn

where n is the number of elements in the probability distribution and pi is the probability \(p(i)\) of the ith element occuring.

Channel class¶

A channel is a system that takes as input a secret \(x\), whose possible values come from a finite set \(\mathcal{X}\) , and whose only observable behavior is to produce an output \(y\), whose possible values come from a finite set \(\mathcal{Y}\).

class Channel¶

Variables

Distribution prior¶

A Distribution object used to represent the prior probability distribution on the set of secrets.

int num_out¶

The number of outputs in the channel. It is exactly the number of columns in matrix.

std::vector<std::vector<long double>> matrix¶

A channel matrix from \(\mathcal{X}\) to \(\mathcal{Y}\) whose rows give the distribution on the set of outputs. That is, entry matrix[x][y] denotes \(p(y|x)\), the conditional probability of getting output \(y\) given input \(x\). Note that all entries in a channel matrix are between 0 and 1, and each row sums to 1.

Both rows and columns are indexed starting at position 0.

Note

To create a Channel object you need first to create a Distribution object, that keeps the prior distribution on the set of secrets.

Constructors

Channel()¶

Default constructor.

Channel(Distribution &prior, std::string file)¶

Construtor used when the channel matrix is in a file.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • file –

    File name that contains a channel matrix. The file format must be the following:

    n y
p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

    where n is the number of secrets and y is the number of outputs. Each pij denotes \(p(j|i)\) - the conditional probability of getting output \(j\) given input \(i\). Each two numbers must be separated by a space.

Channel(Distribution &prior, std::vector<std::vector<long double>> &matrix)¶

Constructor used when there is already a channel matrix in a variable.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • matrix – A channel matrix.

Warning

The number of rows in the channel matrix must be equal to prior.num_el.

Channel(Distribution &prior, int num_out)¶

Constructor used to generate random channels. Given a set of secrets on prior, the constructor builds a random channel matrix.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • num_out – Number of outputs.

Public functions

static bool isChannel(std::vector<std::vector<long double>> &matrix)¶

Verifies if a matrix is a valid channel matrix. A channel matrix is valid if each row corresponds to a probability distribution.

Parameters

matrix – A channel matrix.

Returns

true if the matrix is valid or false otherwise.

std::string toString(int precision)¶

Generates a string with the channel matrix.

Parameters

precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

Returns

A string in the following format:

p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

where n is the number of secrets and y is the number of outputs. Each pij denotes p(j|i), the conditional probability of getting output j given input i. Each two numbers must be separated by a space.

void printToFile(std::string file, int precision)¶

Prints the channel matrix in a file.

Parameters

  • file – File name to print the distribution.

  • precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

The channel matrix will be printed in the following format:

n y
p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

where n is the number of secrets and y is the number of outputs. Each pij denotes p(j|i), the conditional probability of getting output j given input i. Each two numbers must be separated by a space.

Hyper Class¶

Definition of hyper-distribution:

If \(\mathcal{X}\) is a finite set (of possible secret values), \(\pi\) is the prior distribution on \(\mathcal{X}\), and \(C\) is a channel, a hyper-distribution \([\pi \triangleright C]\) resulted from \(C\) on \(\pi\) is a distribution on distributions on \(\mathcal{X}\). Each output in an informational channel is a possible “world”, and each possible world is a new distribution on the set of secrets. We call the possible worlds the inner distributions. Each possible world has a probability of occurring, and we call the distribution on the possible worlds as the outer distribution.

class Hyper¶

Variables

Distribution prior¶

A probability distribution on a set of secrets.

Channel channel¶

An informational channel.

int num_post¶

The number of posterior distributions yielded by channel and prior.

Note

The number of posterior distributions can be different from the number of outputs in channel. See labels for more details.

std::vector<std::vector<long double>> joint¶

Joint distribution matrix.

It is a matrix \(n\) x \(y\) where \(n\) is the number of secrets in the channel and \(y\) is the number of outputs in the channel. Each value joint[i][j] is the joint probability \(p(i,j)\). The joint distribution is build by multiplying the prior distribution by each row of the channel matrix.

Distribution outer¶

A distribution on posterior distributions.

Each value outer.prob[i] is the probability \(p(i)\) of the ith posterior distribution occuring, with \(0 \leq i <\) num_post-1.

std::vector<std::vector<long double>> inners¶

Inner distributions matrix. It is a matrix \(n\) x \(y\) where \(n\) is the number of secrets (prior.num_el) and \(y\) is the number of posterior distributions (num_post). Each value inners[i][j] corresponds to the conditional probability \(p(i|j)\), that is, the probability of the secret being i when the output is j. Each column is a posterior distribution.

Both rows and columns are indexed starting at position 0.

std::map<int, std::set<int>> labels¶

A map from posterior dsitributions indexes to a set of channel outputs indexes. When we look at the hyper-distrubtion, we have the outer distribution and the inner distributions. Depending on the prior distribution and the channel, the hyper-distribution may have two different outputs which yield the same posterior distribution on the set of secrets, and in this case, there is no difference for the adversary observing both.

Indeed we can simplify the representation of a hyper-distribution matrix mergin all equal columns in a single column, and sum their outer probabilities. We also delete a posterior column when its outer probability of ocurring is 0 (which means that this “world” has 0 probability of occuring).

  • The map key is the index of a posterior distribution in the reduced hyper-distribution matrix.

  • The map value of a key i is the set of channel outputs indexes which gave rise this single posterior distribution i.

Example: If the outputs 2 and 4 from the channel yield the same posterior distribution, they are merged in, for example, the 3rd posterior distribution. Then, labels[2] (the 3rd posterior has index 2), you will have the set \(\{2,4\}\).

Constructors

Hyper()¶

Default constructor.

Hyper(std::string prior_file, std::string channel_file)¶

Constructor used when the prior distribution on the set of secrets and the channel are in a file.

Parameters

  • prior_file –

    File name that contains a probability distribution.

    The file format must be the following:

    n
p1
p2
...
pn

    where n is the number of elements in the distribution and pi is the probability of the ith element occuring.

  • channel_file –

    File name that contains a channel matrix.

    The file format must be the following:

    n y
p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

    where n is the number of secrets and y is the number of outputs. Each pij value denotes \(p(j|i)\), the conditional probability of getting output \(j\) given input \(i\). Each two numbers must be separated by a space.

Warning

The number of rows in the channel matrix must be equal to the number of elements in the prior distribution.

Hyper(Channel &channel)¶

Constructor used when there is already a Channel object in a variable.

Note

As a channel has the attribute prior (that corresponds to the prior distribution on the set of secrets), it is not necessary to give a Distribution parameter in this constructor.

Parameters

channel – A Channel object.

Public functions

std::string toString(std::string type, int precision)¶

Generates a string with the joint matrix, the outer distribution, the inners or the labels.

Parameters

  • type – The name of what will be returned. It must be "labels", "joint", "outer" or "inners".

  • precision – Decimal precision for float numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

  • The joint matrix will be returned in the following format:

    p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

    where n is the number of secrets, y is the number of channel outputs and pij is the joint probability \(p(i,j)\).

  • The outer distribution will be returned in the following format:

    p1 p2 ... py

    where y is the number of outputs.

  • The inners matrix will be returned in the following format:

    p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

    where n is the number of secrets, y is the number of outputs and pij is the conditional probability \(p(i|j)\).

  • The labels will be returned in the following format:

    1: x11 x12 ...
2: x21 x22 ...
...
3: xn1 xn2 ...

    where n is the number of posteriors (num_post) and xij is an integer between 0 and channel.num_out.

Each two numbers in any choice are separated by a space.

void printToFile(std::string type, std::string file, int precision)¶

Prints the joint matrix, outer distribution, inners or the labels in a file.

Parameters

  • type – The name of what will be returned. It must be "labels", "joint", "outer" or "inners".

  • file – File name.

  • precision – Decimal precision for float numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

  • The joint matrix will be printed in the following format:

    n y
p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

where n is the number of secrets, y is the number of channel outputs and pij is the joint probability \(p(i,j)\).

  • The outer distribution will be printed in the following format:

    y
p1
p2
...
py

where y is the number of posterior distributions (num_post) and pi is the probability \(p(i)\) of the ith posterior distribution ocurring.

  • The inners matrix will be printed in the following format:

    n y
p11 p12 ... p1y
p21 p22 ... p2y
...
pn1 pn2 ... pny

where n is the number of secrets, y is the number of posterior distributions (num_post) and pij is the conditional probability \(p(i|j)\).

  • The labels will be printed in the following format:

    y
1: x11 x12 ...
2: x21 x22 ...
...
y: xy1 xy2 ...

where y is the number of posterior distributions (num_post) and xij is an integer between 0 and channel.num_out.

Each two numbers in any choice are are separated by a space.

void rebuildHyper(Distribution &prior)¶

Given a new prior distribution, rebuild the joint, outer and inner distributions.

Parameters

prior – Prior distribution on a set of secrets.

Warning

The number of rows in the current channel matrix must be equal to the number of elements in the new prior distribution.

void rebuildHyper(Channel &channel)¶

Given a new channel, rebuild the joint, outer and inner distributions.

Parameters

channel – Informational channel.

Warning

The number of rows in the new channel matrix must be equal to the number of elements in the current prior distribution.

Gain class¶

Definition of a gain function:

Given a finite, non-empty set \(\mathcal{X}\) (of possible secret values) and a non-empty set \(W\) (of possible actions), a gain function is a function \(g: W \times \mathcal{X} \rightarrow R\). The idea is that \(g(w, x)\) specifies the gain that the adversary achieves by taking action \(w\) when the actual value of the secret is \(x\).

class Gain¶

Variables

int num_act¶

Number of distinct actions that an adversary can take. This attribute is exactly the number of rows in matrix.

Distribution prior¶

A probability distribution on a set of secrets. It is a distribution on the set of secrets. See Distribution for more details.

std::vector<std::vector<long double>> matrix¶

Gain function matrix. It is a matrix \(w \times n\) where \(w\) is the number of actions that the adversary can take and \(n\) is the number of secrets. Each value matrix[i][j] is the gain that the adversary achieves by taking action i when the actual value of the secret is j.

Both rows and columns are indexed starting at position 0.

Constructors

Gain()¶

Default constructor.

Gain(Distribution &prior, std::string file)¶

Construtor used when the gain function matrix is in a file.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • file –

    File name which contains a gain function matrix. The file format must be the following:

    w n
g11 g12 ... g1n
g21 g22 ... g2n
...
gw1 gw2 ... gwn

    where w is the number of actions (num_act) and n is the number of secrets. Each value gij is the gain of taking action i when the secret value is j. Each two numbers must be separated by a space.

Warning

The number of columns in the gain function matrix must be the same as prior.num_el, i.e. the number of secrets in the distribution given in the first parameter.

Gain(Distribution &prior, std::vector<std::vector<long double>> &matrix)¶

Constructor used when there is already a gain function matrix in a variable.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • matrix – A gain function matrix.

Warning

The number of columns in the gain function matrix must be the same as prior.num_el, i.e. the number of secrets in the distribution given in the first parameter.

Gain::Gain(Distribution &prior, int num_act, int MIN, int MAX)¶

Constructor used to generate a random gain function.

Parameters

  • prior – Prior distribution on the set of secrets.

  • num_act – Number of actions.

  • MIN – Lower bound for the gain of an action.

  • MAX – Upper bound for the gain of an action.

The parameters MIN and MAX must make up an interval. All the gains will be generated randomly in the interval [MIN,MAX].

Public functions

std::string toString(int precision)¶

Generates a string with the gain function matrix.

Parameters

precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

Returns

The gain function matrix will be returned in the following format:

g11 g12 ... g1n
g21 g22 ... g2n
...
gw1 gw2 ... gwn

where each gain gij is the gain of taking action i when the secret value is j. Each two numbers are separated by a space.

void printToFile(std::string file, int precision)¶

Prints the gain function matrix in a file.

Parameters

  • file – File name.

  • precision – Decimal precision for long double numbers. For example, use the value 3 to print 0.322, use 5 to print 0.32197, and so on.

The gain function matrix will be printed in the following format:

w n
g11 g12 ... g1n
g21 g22 ... g2n
...
gw1 gw2 ... gwn

where w is the number of actions (num_act) and n is the number of secrets. Each gain gij is the gain of taking action i when the secret value is j. Each two numbers are sparated by a space.
